Project Description: To support a Community Arts Development project in partnership with other community organizations. The project is a cultural tourism effort to promote the "Hot Times Community Arts  Music Festival, " that includes theater performances, poetry presentations, storytelling, and musical presentations for an audience drawn from throughout central Ohio. Partnering organizations will include the Main Street Business Assoication, City of Columbus, Columbus Health Department, and ComFest.
To support a Community Arts Development project in partnership with other community organizations
To support activities that contribute to your creative development and artistic growth and may include writing, research, and travel

Purpose: To support artist fees for a mixed-repertoire program by choreographers Leiland Charles, Dana Genshaft, and Amy Seiwert. Additional Project Description: Each choreographer is commissioned to create a new work for BalletMet, to be performed at the Davidson Theatre in Columbus, Ohio. Associated engagement activities may include post-performance discussions and discounted tickets to a dress rehearsal for senior citizens. Intended Beneficiaries: This project will benefit audiences in Columbus, Ohio. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support dancer salaries and license and acquisition fees for mixed repertory dance performances by Ballet Met. Additional Project Description: The program will include works by choreographers George Balanchine, Edwaard Liang, and Christopher Wheeldon. Performances will take place at Davidson Theatre in downtown Columbus, Ohio. Intended Beneficiaries: Audiences in the greater Columbus area will benefit from this production. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

To support the creation of new ballets by BalletMet dancers. The program will include open rehearsals and will expand the dancers' choreographic careers under the mentorship of Artistic Director Edwaard Liang.

To support a program of ballets choreographed by Artistic Director Edwaard Liang. The company will perform Symphonic Dances set to music by Sergei Rachmaninoff, Beautiful Child set to vocal covers by Rufus Wainwright, and Wünderland set to music by Philip Glass. Community engagement activities may include in-school performances with audience interaction and information about the program and the creative process, and discounted tickets for seniors to attend a dress rehearsal.

To support the presentation of "Romeo and Juliet," by Edwaard Liang. BalletMet will stage this three-act performance for its Ohio premiere which will include elaborate sets and costumes, swordfights, and dramatic choreography. Students in BalletMet's Dance Academy will be cast in a variety of character roles. Educational components will include a performance for school children and study materials for teachers to integrate in their classrooms. The ballet will be performed at the Ohio Theatre in Columbus.

To support the presentation of the performance program "Inspired," in collaboration with the Cincinnati Ballet. The works will include Artistic Director Edwaard Liang's "Age of Innocence," a work by Cincinnati Ballet, and George Balanchine's "Who Cares?" BalletMet Columbus and Cincinnati Ballet will collaborate to form the larger ensemble cast required for "Who Cares?" BalletMet is planning a Movement Makers outreach initiative that will focus on Balanchine's legacy and will dedicate a link on their website about Balanchine in conjunction with videos, interviews, blogs, and social media. A Movement Makers "Informance" will include BalletMet 2 (the pre-professional student company) performing excerpts of "Age of Innocence," and will be performed at no or low cost for inner-city schools and community sites. Additional outreach activities include post-performance discussions, a discounted senior dress rehearsal, and BalletMet's KidTix program. The performances will take place in Columbus and Cincinnati.

To support the presentation of American Masters. Performances will include Jerome Robbins' "Fancy Free," a full ensemble work by Artistic Director Edwaard Liang, and works by choreographers James Kudelka and David Nixon. During the creation and rehearsal process, Ballet Met 2 dancers will perform sections of "Fancy Free" at Columbus area schools and businesses. In addition, the company will host open rehearsals at its studios with choreographers, dancers, and artistic staff. Other outreach activities may include post-performance discussions, a discounted senior dress rehearsal, and BalletMet KidTix, which offers free performance tickets for underserved children and young adults.

To support the creation and presentation of dance works. The program, titled New Works/New Direction, will feature works created by new Artistic Director Edwaard Liang, choreographer Christopher Wheeldon, and choreographer Gustavo Ramirez Sansano. A variety of educational and outreach activities will complement the project, including open rehearsals at Ballet Met's studios, pre- and post-performance discussions, and student matinees. Performances will take place at the Columbus' Capitol Theatre.

To support the creation and presentation of world premieres by choreographers Jimmy Orrante and Amy Seiwert. Orrante will collaborate with media composer Sean Beeson, with technical support from the Ohio State University Advanced Computer Center for the Arts and Design to create an interactive environment; Amy Seiwert and software artist Frieder Weiss will create a second work to music by composer Daniel Bernard Roumain.

To support the world premiere of "7 Deadly Sins" created for BalletMet Columbus. Choreographers Dwight Rhoden, Ma Cong, Gina Patterson, James Kudelka, and Amy Seiwert will create the work in collaboration with Columbus-based Shadowbox, a performance troupe known its musical theater productions.

To support the creation and presentation of world premiere works by choreographers Ma Cong, Maurice Hines, James Kudelka, and Darrell Grand Moultrie. Each choreographic residency will culminate in public performances at the Capital Theatre in downtown Columbus, Ohio.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support the creation and presentation of new works as part of the BalletMet Columbus' 30th Anniversary. The works include the company premiere of SINATRA SUITE by Twyla Tharp, the world premiere of A DIFFERENT DRUMMER by Alexander Schneider-Rossmy, and the world premiere of ALADDIN by artistic director Gerard Charles, in collaboration with Phoenix Theatre Circle.

To support the presentation of Jazz Moves. The collaborative project between BalletMet Columbus and Jazz Arts Group will include multiple new works by choreographers and composers, exploring jazz through music and dance.

To support the creation and world premiere production of "Firebird" by choreographer Stanton Welch. Welch will set his Firebird to the orchestral suite composed by Igor Stravinsky that incorporates elements from the ballet score commissioned in 1910 by Russian choreographer Serge Diaghilev.

To support the creation and presentation of a full-length ballet by choreographer Stanton Welch. Evolution will be created in three acts to the music "Corroboree" by Australian John Antill, "Eine Kleine Nachtmusik" by Mozart, and songs by Moby.
To support the commissioning of a world premiere by choreographer Stanton Welch. The Australian choreographer will create Don Quixote for BalletMet's 25th anniversary.
To support the commissioning of a new work. Birgit Scherzer will premiere the work during one of the company's seasons.

To support three initiatives within its expanded DanceReach educational outreach programs. These initiatives include BalletMet's Dance Camp for SummerDance 1999, a residency program expansion, and a Distance Learning project.

To support the commissioning of a dance work by choreographer Julia Adam which will premiere in Columbus, Ohio. This commission is part of BalletMet's New Moves program dedicated to the creation of new work and the restaging of contemporary masterworks. Julia Adam, the choreographer, is a principal dancer with the San Francisco ballet, and is rapidly developing a distinct choreographic voice. BalletMet was the first professional company to commission her choreography; Innocence and Experience premiered on the company's March 1997 series to audience and critical acclaim.

Purpose: To support a series of free, interdisciplinary, and intergenerational outdoor performances. Additional Project Description: The outdoor performance series will launch with the Global Water Dances project, which features professionals in dance, music, spoken word, and live painting appearing side-by-side with teen and young adult artists. The series also includes other performances of multidisciplinary work, including spoken word, music, and live painting. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve low-income residents of Columbus, Ohio. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

To support part of the conservation of a seven-canvas mural by Emerson Burkhart. Commissioned by the Columbus Board of Education with funding from the Public Works of Art Project (a precursor to the Works Progress Administration), the mural, Music, was originally installed in 1934 in a high school auditorium.

Organization Name: Columbus Association for the Performing Arts
Project Description: To support the production of "American Buffalo" by David Mamet. CAPA and Deaf West Theatre will partner to produce a bi-lingual production that will integrate American Sign Language (ASL) and spoken English, reaching out to audiences that are deaf or hard of hearing.

Organization Name: Columbus Association for the Performing Arts
Project Description: To support a consortium project to commission the adaptation and translation of "The Secret Garden" for both deaf and hearing audiences in partnership with Deaf West Theatre. Deaf West Theatre will later tour the production to several U.S. cities.

Organization Name: Columbus Association for the Performing Arts
Project Description: To support a revival of "Big River: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," presented in an American Sign Language (ASL) adaptation. Produced jointly by Deaf West Theatre and Roundabout Theatre Company, the musical includes deaf, hard-of-hearing, and hearing actors performing in both spoken English and ASL.

To support the Aminah Robinson Legacy Project. The project will include documentation, preservation, conservation, and presentation of Robinson's (1940-2015) work that includes hand-carved painted doors, photographs, and early paintings, as well as items Robinson collected. The exhibit is scheduled for the summer through the end of the year. Plans include potentially using Robinson's house as an artist-in-residence space to inspire emerging artists and engage the local community.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support Teen Open Studio, a drop-in art program offered free to central Ohio teens. Offered twice a week, the program will give teenagers in the region the opportunity to develop creative skills by experimenting with new and traditional media while supported by peers, mentors, community partners, and visiting creative professionals. By working with local artists, participating students will develop creative and critical thinking skills that are important for later success in college and beyond.

To support the exhibition "I, Too, Sing America: The Harlem Renaissance at 100." Celebrating the centennial of this astonishing outpouring of African-American creativity that occurred internationally in the 1920s and '30s, the exhibition will highlight painting, works-on-paper, photography, and ephemera of the Harlem Renaissance. Curated by Columbus native and acclaimed writer Wil Haygood, the exhibition will include work by Jacob Lawrence, Romare Bearden, Aaron Douglas, and others who interpreted the lives of African Americans during this era, as well as unprinted photographs by James Van Der Zee obtained through the artist's estate and a private collection of vernacular photographs of African-American life. A selection of books, sheet music, and print ephemera will further showcase the innovative and expansive cultural output produced in Harlem during this unforgettable epoch of American history. To complement the exhibition and further its community outreach, a collective of Columbus arts organizations will partner to present a season of related programming.

To support the re-installation of select works in the museum and its sculpture garden. With the completion of a new wing, the museum will now be able to install major pieces that had never before been exhibited, or had been exhibited in less than ideal conditions. The project will engage the public with the newly installed works by artists such as Mel Chin, Josiah McElheny, Jennifer West, Alison Saar, and Alexander Calder.

To support "A Dangerous Woman: Subversion and Surrealism in the Art of Honore Sharrer." The first major reassessment of Sharrer (1920-2009) since her death, the exhibition will include approximately 45 of her paintings, plus associated sketches, drawings, photographs, and prints.

To support "PUBLIC[Space]," a series of outreach programs to engage teenagers. Designed to promote civic responsibility while fostering critical thinking and creativity, the project features a year-long internship program for approximately teens who meet weekly at the museum.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support "Columbus In-Focus," a digital photography education program. Students will work together to explore the power of documentary photography as an art form that captures history, culture, communities, and individual stories by examining original art at the Museum; they will receive first-hand experience with practicing artists and create their own documentary photography using digital cameras.
To support the Art Matters Collection Project. Project activities include the preparation and relocation of CMA's collections during large-scale renovation and expansion of its building.

To support the touring exhibition George Tooker: A Retrospective, with accompanying catalogue and education programs in consortium with the National Academy of Design in New York. The exhibition, undertaken in partnership with the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, will present a comprehensive survey and critical reassessment of George Tooker's (American, b. 1920) work and his place in American art, which has long been overlooked.

To support The Art Matters Collection Project. The project will prepare the bulk of the collection for transport to safe climate-controlled, off-site storage during a major expansion and renovation of the museum's campus.

To support the touring exhibition "Circle of Bliss: The Meditational Tradition of Tibet and Nepal," with accompanying catalogue and education programs. The exhibition will examine Tibetan art in the context of past and present-day Buddhist ritual.

To support transportation for school children to performances of the Columbus Symphony and Jazz Arts Group. Each of the participating organizations provides pre-concert text that is written to student's reading level and provides Columbus fourth and fifth graders with the opportunity to experience a variety of musical genres and performances.

To support free outdoor video simulcasts of orchestral concerts and a radio broadcast. The opening and closing season concerts in the Ohio Theater, conducted by Music Director Jean-Marie Zeitouni, will be videotaped live and projected on large video screens to audiences on the Columbus Commons Park.

To support the Contemporary Music Festival, in consortium with Ohio State University (OSU). The five-day festival of new music will feature performances of works by composer-in-residence Augusta Read Thomas.

To support the Contemporary Music Festival, a consortium project with Ohio State University. The six-day festival of new music will feature the works of Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Gunther Schuller.

To support the Contemporary Music Festival, a consortium project with Ohio State University. Te festival of new music will feature the works of composer Olly Wilson and other living, African American composers.
To support the Contemporary Music Festival, a consortium project. The five-day festival of new music will feature the work of composer Lou Harrison.

To support a festival of contemporary music, a consortium project. Columbus Symphony Orchestra and Ohio State University will present a festival of concerts and lecture with composer Krzysztof Penderecki.
To support "The Holocaust: An Artist's Perspective." Project components include a concert, teacher seminar, classroom visits, student-produced video documentary and an archival exhibit.

To support the Elementary School Young People's Concerts and the accompanying SEATS (Symphony Education and Audience Training the Schools) curriculum booklets. The Symphony musicians will perform full orchestral concerts, as well as ensemble programs and educational activities, for central Ohio's school children.

To support the Columbus Symphony Orchestra's Musicians in the Schools program. During 2000-01, this newly-focused program will serve second through fourth grade classrooms in central Ohio's underserved schools that have minimal or non-existent music programs.

To support JAZZ ON THE AVENUE, a concert series showcasing traditional jazz and other musical forms influenced by jazz. The 2012 Jazz on the Avenue will feature musicians Aaron Diehl, Paul Taylor, and others.

To support the presentation of DanceAfrica, a weekend-long celebration at the King Arts Complex. The celebration will showcase dancing and drumming, as well as an African marketplace featuring area vendors offering crafts, food, and fashion, and an African Art exhibition in the King Arts Complex Gallery.
To support the presentation of Muntu Dance Theater of Chicago. The company will offer performances, classes, and workshops in African and African American dance, music, and folklore.

To support the presentation of Marc Bamuthi Joseph's "Words Become Flesh" and associated outreach lecture/demonstrations. Individuals from the low-income African American neighborhood around the King Arts Complex and youth from schools is an empowerment zone will find the performances accessible.

To support the presentation of "Flow," a one-man show by Will Power. The solo-performances of acclaimed hip-hop performer and writer Will Power will reach young urban and African-American audiences in Central Ohio; Mr. Power will also conduct workshops for youth groups in the community on storytelling and acting.
To support "All That Dance: A Multidisciplinary Exploration," including dance presentations, an exhibition, and related outreach activities.

To support Sister Talk, a series of presentations, lectures, and workshops celebrating the accomplishments of African American women in literature. Featured artists include Sonia Sanchez, J. California Cooper, and Julia Hare.

To support "Black History and the New Millennium," a series placing special emphasis on the artistic contributions of Black males. Funds will support artists' fees, educational activities, marketing, and free tickets targeting underserved youth and adult populations.
To support the translation from Persian of a selection of the poetry of the 14th century Persian princess Jahan Khatun.

To support the development of an annual children's magazine dedicated to the visual arts for the Midwest region. Tentatively titled "smART," the publication will be targeted to rural sixth-graders who do not typically have access to museums and galleries.
To support publication of the "Focus" section in each of six issues of this regional art journal. Each section will highlight a particular community or topic through a series of feature articles.

To support fees for writers and photographers, and associated costs for the "Reviews" section of five issues of Dialogue: the arts in the midwest. Since 1978, Dialogue has served the Midwestern region Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, and Illinois as a journal with feature articles, reviews, calendar and opportunity listings, news regarding gallery and museum openings, and information on grants and deadlines. For the "Reviews" section, the executive and managing editors will work with corresponding editors and writers throughout the region to cover events presented at venues ranging from small, alternative spaces and temporary sites to well established museums and art centers. Editors and writers come from throughout the region and have varying levels of education, experience, and expertise. The magazine is sent to subscribers and retail stores via Ingram Periodicals and Ohio Periodical Distributors; it is also committed to a complimentary distribution program reaching underserved areas of the population as well as established art communities in metropolitan areas. The magazine is committed to assisting new writers in developing a critical voice. Each issue of Dialogue reaches approximately 30,000 people.

Organization Name: Franklin Park Conservatory Joint Recreation District
Project Description: To support the exhibition Bending Nature. The exhibition will include new commissions and existing works by as many as 16 artists in an investigation of traditions in botanical design - both Occidental topiary and Oriental bonsai.

Organization Name: Fuse Factory Electronic and Digital Arts Lab
Project Description: Purpose: To support Frequency Fridays, a performance series of experimental music, new media, and sound art. Additional Project Description: Presented monthly, the series will feature performances by artists who incorporate electronic or digital technology into their work. Select performers will lead workshops for the public on topics such as algorithmic music, projection mapping, and circuit bending. Intended Beneficiaries: The series will benefit general audiences in the Columbus, Ohio, area, as well as artists working with technology. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support facilities, safety supplies, and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support multidisciplinary "El Dia de los Muertos" (Day of the Dead) events at the Highball Halloween Festival. The festival will include workshops and partnerships with organizations such as Latino Arts for Humanity and the Short North Alliance that will assist with targeted outreach and event coordination.

To support Art Makes Columbus/Columbus Makes Art, a communitywide arts sector marketing campaign. The campaign will raise awareness of the artistic talent in Columbus and the diverse offerings of arts and cultural organizations. The campaign will make use of a multi-faceted promotion strategy that includes a website, social media, live engagement events, and strategic community partnerships to garner the broadest possible support and awareness. The arts council, in collaboration with the Columbus Cultural Leadership Consortium (comprising some of the largest arts and cultural organizations in the city), will lead the effort.

To support a program of temporary public art installations along the riverfront in Columbus, Ohio. In conjunction with upcoming bicentennial celebrations for the city, public art will transform a seven block area surrounding the State House and riverfront to create memorable experiences for workers, citizens, and visitors.
To support Arts CLASSified. This new searchable Web directory highlights providers of community arts education programs within Franklin County, Ohio.

Discipline / Field: Creative Links: Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a Creative Links project to provide positive alternatives for youth. The partnership brings together Americorp, MLK Community Center and the Greater Columbus Arts Council to create Children of the Future, an after-school and summer program for at-risk children, ages 5 to 12, living in high crime neighborhoods. Artists will use drama, creative writing, dance and visual arts activities to help the children develop skills in critical thinking, communication and conflict resolution as they gain greater awareness of their roles and responsibilities in larger communities.

Purpose: To support multidisciplinary arts education programming and the presentation of a community chorus. Additional Project Description: Weekly arts education sessions will be offered free-of-charge in schools, correctional facilities, and supportive housing facilities. Arts programming will be supplemented by recreational classes and service learning opportunities to foster creativity, responsibility, self-confidence, and community engagement. The project will culminate in public presentations, including a large-scale community chorus. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit Central Ohio communities, including incarcerated individuals, adults with disabilities, students from low-income households, veterans, and individuals who have experienced homelessness. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.

Purpose: To support a creative writing fellowship. Additional Project Description: This Fellowship will support activities that contribute to the creative development and artistic growth, including writing, research, and travel of the recipient. Intended Beneficiaries: This fellowship will benefit the recipient. Intended Outcomes: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support an artist residency with NEA Jazz Master Maria Schneider. Additional Project Description: The multi-day residency will include musical performances with Schneider guest-conducting the Columbus Jazz Orchestra (CJO) and hosted by trumpet virtuoso and CJO Artistic Director Byron Stripling. Associated educational activities will include master classes and rehearsals with the Capital University Big Band that will be livestreamed to several area universities; a rehearsal with the Columbus Youth Jazz Orchestra; and rehearsals with the Columbus Jazz Orchestra, as well as a livestreamed interview with Schneider made available to the public on the organization's JAG.TV virtual platform. Intended Beneficiaries: Project activities will benefit local patrons, area high school and college-level music students at several universities, and online audiences through livestreaming. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries acquire knowledge and skills in the arts.
To support the Jazz in the Community component of the Jazz Academy. Programming includes music theory classes, workshops, performance ensembles, a mentorship program, and music business sessions.
To support performances of Louis Armstrong's music by members of the Columbus Jazz Orchestra. The project will include educational components, artist workshops, and community outreach.

To support the Jazz Academy components: jazz in the community and jazz in the schools. Programming includes music theory classes, workshops, performance ensembles, a mentorship program, and music business sessions.
To support the inaugural year of a jazz academy. Designed for educating adults as well as children, the academy will offer courses during fall and spring sessions.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work by Jack Clayton for the Columbus Jazz Orchestra. Clayton will provide master classes and coaching to the Columbus Youth Jazz Orchestra and to area high schools and colleges.
To support the preservation of jobs that are threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn.

To support chamber music presentations and residency activities. Children's concerts, programs in retirement communities, master classes, teacher's forums, and open rehearsals are planned during the residencies.

To support the creation and presentation of a new work for string quartet by composer Donald Harris, including outreach activities. The new work will be premiered by the St. Petersburg String Quartet.

Category: Challenge America Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a partnership project of artist-led activities that provides positive alternatives for youth.

To support a consortium project involving the Jefferson Academy of Music and the Chamber Music Society of St. Cloud to commission a new work by composer Gunther Schuller for violin, cello, piano, and French horn, to be performed by the Walden Horn Trio with cellist Fred Sherry during residencies in Ohio and Minnesota.
To support an exhibition series featuring the work of contemporary African American and African diaspora artists. Participating artists will be those who reside or have ties in the Ohio region.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel, facilities, safety supplies, and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support folk arts educational outreach and a traditional arts apprenticeship program. Additional Project Description: A comprehensive folk arts-in-education program will offer K-12 folk arts residencies; an online program for instructing local folk artists in teaching methods; and a workshop, open to all, offering instruction in interview and documentation skills. Additionally, the project will support a pilot folk arts apprenticeship program and a countywide folklife survey. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit K-12 students, teachers, and folk artists in Marion County, Ohio. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel and safety supplies expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Purpose: To support a series of multidisciplinary arts and cultural programming. Additional Project Description: Arts and culture activities will include the creation of murals, an artist residency, workshops, a mobile storytelling station, and arts education offerings. Programming will focus on imagining a future where Black people thrive and are free from oppression. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the participating artists and general audiences in Columbus, Ohio, with a focus on serving underserved communities. Intended Outcome: Communities are strengthened through systemwide initiatives integrated with the arts.

Purpose: To support Deliver Black Dreams, a series of multidisciplinary arts and cultural programming. Additional Project Description: Arts and culture activities will include the creation of murals, an artist residency, documentary screenings, photography exhibitions, and arts education offerings. Programming will focus on imagining a future where Black people thrive and are free from oppression. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve underserved communities in Columbus, Ohio. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.
To support the translation from Arabic of poems by Iraqi poet Saadi Youssef. Spanning forty years, the poems will form the first book-length rendition of his work in English.

Organization Name: Ohio Alliance for Arts In Education
Project Description: To support a consortium project for an arts assessment in Ohio's schools. The project will further refine, implement and publicize quality arts assessment, adding components for arts organizations, developing demonstration sites and linking arts assessment to student learning and curriculum planning.

Organization Name: Ohio Alliance for Arts In Education
Project Description: To support the Ohio Arts Education Assessment Project, a consortium effort with the Ohio Arts Council and Department of Education to create, test, refine and disseminate assessment instruments for grades four and eight in dance, drama/theater, music, and visual arts, and to enable Ohio administrators and teachers to plan and conduct arts assessments in their schools and districts In 1996 Ohio's Board of Education approved a new curriculum framework, which calls for both assessment of student progress in the arts and standardized annual district-wide, grade-level tests and ongoing assessment of student progress. Currently, sample assessments are not available, and many school personnel feel at a loss as to how to begin this assessment work due to lack of knowledge, experience, strategies and examples. This awareness led to a series of planning meetings among the consortium partners; this project was developed out of their work together. In Phase 1, assessment writing teams will develop sample instruments, which will be compiled, published and distributed to every elementary and middle school in the state. During Phase 2, a 6-day assessment trainer institute will be developed and conducted to create up to 12 regional, 4-member teams of assessment trainers who will provide peer-to-peer professional development in their regions. In Phase 3, the trainers will conduct workshops in their regions to develop teachers' and administrators' ability to plan and conduct arts assessments.

Purpose: To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out the agency’s National Endowment for the Arts-approved strategic plan. Additional Project Description: Funding will support state plan priorities, arts education initiatives, underserved communities, the Poetry Out Loud program, and folk and traditional arts programs. The project includes subgranting activity. Intended Beneficiaries: Residents of the agency’s state, including youth, artists, arts organizations, and the general public will benefit from the award. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries experience the exchange of artists, artworks, and arts activities.
To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out the agency’s National Endowment for the Arts-approved strategic plan.

To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out the agency’s National Endowment for the Arts-approved strategic plan, and subgranting to the nonprofit arts sector in order to preserve jobs and maintain operations to fuel the recovery of the nation’s arts sector from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out the agency’s National Endowment for the Arts-approved strategic plan, as well as salaries, administration costs, and related subgranting to the nonprofit arts sector in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
To support arts programs, services, and activities associated with carrying out your agency’s NEA-approved strategic plan.
To support Partnership Agreement activities associated with carrying out your NEA-approved State strategic plan
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support Partnership Agreement activities.
To support Partnership Agreement activities,
To support Partnership Agreement activities,
To support Partnership Agreement activities,
To support Partnership Agreement activities,
To support Partnership Agreement activities,
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support arts projects and activities which preserve jobs in the nonprofit arts sector threatened by declines in philanthropic and other support during the current economic downturn
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support Partnership Agreement activities.
To support state participation in Poetry Out Loud: National Recitation Contest and state-level finals.
To support Partnership Agreement activities.

To support continuation of the Ohio Folk Arts Initiative. Core activities will include fieldwork and documentation, the Ohio Heritage Fellowship Program, presentation of folk and traditional artists at the Cityfolk Festival, and support of archival activities for folk arts material collected throughout the state.
To support Partnership Agreement activities

To support continuation of the Ohio Folk Arts Initiative. Core activities will include fieldwork and documentation, continuation of the Ohio Heritage Fellowship Program, presentation of folk and traditional arts at the Cityfolk Festival, and maintenance of the Web site.

To support the continuation of the Ohio Folk Arts Initiative. Project activities will include fieldwork/archive updates; festival presentations; continuation of the Ohio Heritage Fellowship Program and Ohio Folk Arts Network; and maintenance of the Web site.
To support Partnership Agreement activities

To support the continuation of the Ohio Folk Arts Initiative. Project activities will include fieldwork and documentation, the creation of an Ohio Heritage Fellowship Program, presentations of Ohio folk/traditional artists at the Cityfolk Festival, and expansion and updating of the Web site.
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support ADA Cultural Access Training workshops, the Artists with Disabilities Professional Development Fund, and technical assistance for accessibility surveys.

To support the establishment of an Ohio Heritage Fellows Program, fieldwork, presentations of folk artists, and other related costs. These activities will help to ensure that folk and traditional arts will hold a vital place in the artistic and cultural endeavors of the Arts Council, as well as those carried out by other organizations in the state.
To support Partnership Agreement activities

To support the Ohio Traditional Arts Initiative. This project provides for a folk and traditional arts advisory committee, fieldwork and documentation, presentation of traditional artists at the CITYFOLK Festival and construction of a world wide web site.
To support Partnership Agreement activities
To support Partnership Agreement activities

To support the Ohio Traditional Arts Initiative. This project provides for an advisory committee, fieldwork and documentation, presentations of a significant number of Ohio folk and traditional artists at the annual CITYFOLK Festival and updating of the World Wide Web site.
To support the Traditional Arts Initiative, a project that provides for fieldwork and documentation, an advisory committee, presentations, and publications.
To support Partnership Agreement activities.

To support research, an internet broadcast, publications, and related costs for the arts and public policy symposium, Going Global: Negotiating the Maze of Cultural Interactions. This symposium will focus on issues surrounding globalization of arts and culture and will be held May 4 - 6, 2000, in Columbus, Ohio.

Category: Learning in the Arts for Children & Youth
Project Description: To support the Institute for Arts Partners. The project will involve teams of practitioners and school administrators who will focus on academic content standards and curriculum development and assessment, as well as the development of effective partnerships with community leaders and artists.

Purpose: To support a longitudinal qualitative study exploring both the struggles and creative resilience of working artists throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: Researchers will conduct follow-up interviews with artists from a wide range of artistic fields who were initially interviewed in the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as conduct new interviews with additional artists. In these interviews, researchers will oversample artists of color and artists at risk of ending their artistic careers because of situational or structural impediments, such as economic or labor market concerns or caregiving responsibilities. The researchers will systematically analyze the interview data, publish and disseminate the findings, and host a national symposium on the impact of COVID-19 on artists. Intended Beneficiaries: The project has the potential to benefit arts administrators and funders by improving their understanding of artist labor market challenges and opportunities. Intended Outcome: Evidence of the value and impact of the arts is expanded and promoted.

To support a meta-analysis on the effects of drama-based pedagogies on literacy-related student outcomes. The study focuses on empirical research literature published from 1985 through the present. Literacy-related outcome areas of interest include achievement (writing and reading), and psychological, social, and behavioral student outcomes in educational settings. The meta-analysis will include published and non-published, and experimental and quasi-experimental, studies involving school-aged children, adolescents, and college students.

To support a symposium and workshop on the use of contemporary digital technologies by women architects and artists. The architects will present their work to a professional and lay audience with special outreach to local high school students.

To support the stabilization and treatment of the James Thurber Collection, Conservation will include de-acidifying, microfilming, re-housing, and copying the collection. The manuscripts, published works, letters, and other materials are threatened by the acidic nature of the papers used by Thurber, a notable 20th-century humorist.

Purpose: To support the OhioDance Virtual Dance Collection®, an interactive website that documents and preserves the achievements of persons and institutions who have shaped the dance history of Ohio. Additional Project Description: The Virtual Dance Collection® team will travel throughout Ohio to conduct interviews, present school residencies, offer film screenings, and display a traveling exhibit. In addition, the team will capture video, still images, and new oral histories to add to the online archive. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will serve the general public, as well as current and future generations of artists, choreographers, students, scholars, and educators. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support the documentation, preservation, and expansion of the OhioDance Virtual Dance Collection®, an archival project of Ohio's dance history for the public domain. Additional Project Description: The Virtual Dance Collection team will travel throughout Ohio to conduct interviews and school residencies, and to capture video, still images, and oral histories. The company seeks to provide a resource for those who have little or no knowledge of dance as well as for those who are deeply engaged in the art form. Intended Beneficiaries: This project serves current and future generations of artists, ensembles, choreographers, students, educators, scholars and the public. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support the continued expansion and development of the OhioDance Virtual Dance Collection. This interactive website documents, preserves, and historicizes the achievements of persons and institutions who have shaped the diversity of dance history and practice within the state of Ohio. The collection is a dance literacy resource for those who have little or no knowledge of dance in the state, as well as for those who are deeply engaged in the art form. This project serves current and future generations of artists, ensembles, choreographers, students, educators, scholars, and the public.

To support the continued expansion and development of the OhioDance Virtual Dance Collection, an archive of Ohio's dance history for the public domain. The Virtual Dance Collection will continue to reflect the cultural attitudes about the social and political climate of the times, including women’s voting rights, the women’s movement, civil rights, disability rights, and how this influenced artistic expression. This project honors the Women's Suffrage Centennial.

To support the virtual archiving and accessibility of Ohio's dance history. The collection will be expanded with additional interviews, and the development of workshops and materials to build dance literacy that will be shared with schools throughout Ohio. Work will continue on a documentary film in support of the archive. The project will honor historic contributions to dance in Ohio and create visibility for Ohio artists, while engaging the general public, and current and future dance audiences, with an understanding of the importance of dance literacy.

To support the creation of a documentary film based on the OhioDance Virtual Dance Collection and the expansion of the online archive. The project will include the creation of a documentary film, the expansion of the collection with additional interviews, and the development of workshops and materials to build dance literacy that will be shared with schools throughout Ohio. The project will honor historic contributions to dance in Ohio and create visibility for Ohio artists, while engaging the general public and current and future dance audiences with an understanding of the importance of dance literacy.

To support the Virtual Dance Collection Project of Ohio. An interactive website will be created to capture the most significant dance moments in Ohio during the last 50 years, and to make that information accessible to the public. OhioDance will select dance moments, create content, design the website, and unveil the project to the community with performances by some of the collection's dance artists.

Purpose: To support the professional world premiere of Alice Tierney by composer Melissa Dunphy and librettist Jacqueline Goldfinger by Opera Columbus. Additional Project Description: The opera uses the Rashomon effect in its storytelling, in which multiple people tell the same story in different ways, to explore the perspectives of four archeologists who uncover clues surrounding the mysterious death of a woman in 1880. A collaboration with Oberlin Conservatory of Music, the production will be initially workshopped and performed at the school prior to the professional premiere performance by Opera Columbus. Intended Beneficiaries: Activities will benefit audiences in the Columbus, Ohio, metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Purpose: To support 40 Days of Opera, a citywide programming series that will include performances of Verdi's Traviata and a concert performance of Leslie Savoy Burr’s Vanqui as part of Opera Columbus' 40th anniversary season. Additional Project Description: Project activities will also include the creation of a public mural celebrating opera, drive-in opera events combining opera and popular films, storytelling programs for children, and additional community engagement events in partnership with local organizations. Intended Beneficiaries: Activities will benefit audiences in the Columbus metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

To support Opera Columbus' new production of Puccini's La Bohème. The opera about early 19th-century bohemians in Paris will be staged in Columbus's modern-day "bohemian" artists space—a century-old former factory converted to a creative artists space. Performed in the round, with the orchestra on each side of the stage and the audience seated along the other two sides of the stage, a new chamber orchestration will be created for this production to reflect the nontraditional orchestra setup required by the space. There will be no set, but rather lighting will provide the main visual component, which will be a rock concert aesthetic, and performances in English will feature a new translation.

To support the world premiere performances of The Flood, a new chamber opera by Composer Korine Fujiwara and Librettist Stephen Wadsworth. A co-commission by Opera Columbus and ProMusica Chamber Orchestra, the opera tells the story of human connection through loss and shared tragedy, centered around the devastation of the Franklinton neighborhood in Columbus, Ohio, in the Great Flood of 1913. The premiere performances will be held at the Southern Theatre in Columbus, Ohio.

To support a professional development training collaboration between Opera Columbus and The Juilliard School. In its inaugural year, the collaboration will provide Juilliard's Artist Diploma in Opera Studies participants with employment, a support system, and an environment to try new repertoire, take artistic risks, and work on their craft. Participants will receive professional experience in a regional opera company as they will be engaged to make their professional debut in principal roles in Opera Columbus' mainstage productions. Artistic Director Peggy Kriha Dye will work with Juilliard Director of Opera Studies Stephen Wadsworth to determine principal roles suited for each student, who will be featured in new productions during the year.

To support a production of "The Threepenny Opera" (1928) by Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht, accompanied by the Columbus Jazz Orchestra. Also planned are events designed to educate the public about the cultural, historical, and political context of the work.

Category: Challenge America Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a partnership project of artist-led activities that provides positive alternatives for youth. The partnership with Columbus Symphony Orchestra and the Columbus Children's Choir will provide instruction in opera. Participants between the ages of eight and 18 will receive instruction and take part in activities both after-school and during summer camps.

To support the company's educational programs, with emphasis on longer-term residencies and the integration of opera programming into the classroom curriculum. The touring component of Opera/Columbus's education department will conduct as many as 200 educational events in churches, classrooms, community centers, and senior living-facilities during 2000-01.

To support artists' fees and related costs for the development and and world premiere of the opera "Vanqui," composed by noted jazz musician Leslie Burrs with libretto by novelist John A. Williams. The project will include a workshop concert version in February followed by the premiere in the fall.

Purpose: To support a performance project featuring lost works by Black opera composers. Additional Project Description: A concert of lost operatic works by Black composers from the 20th century will be filmed and formatted for a 30-minute television broadcast on a local TV network affiliate. The creative team for the project, titled I, Too, Sing America, Part II, will include artistic administrator and pianist Ed Bak and Director of Community Affairs and Diversity Project Head Dr. Toni Smith. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will engage audiences of all ages, including school children in the greater Columbus metropolitan area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Organization Name: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
Project Description: To support the commissioning and performance of a new work for violin and chamber orchestra by composer David Fulmer. The premiere will feature guest artist Stefan Jackiw in performance with the orchestra at the historic Southern Theatre in Columbus.

Organization Name: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
Project Description: To support the commissioning and performance of a new work for chamber orchestra and cello by composer Aaron Jay Kernis, including educational outreach activity. Featuring cellist Joshua Roman and music director Dr. Timothy Russell, the project will include open rehearsals for older adults, post-concert discussions with the composer, and a master class for local conservatory students.

Organization Name: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
Project Description: To support the commissioning and premiere performance of a new work for chamber music and two guitars by composer Clarice Assad. The premiere will feature guest artists The Assad Brothers (Sergio and Odair) in performance at the historic Southern Theatre in Columbus.

Organization Name: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
Project Description: To support the commissioning and performance of a new work by composer and violinist Mark O'Connor with related outreach activities. The concerto for chamber orchestra and piano trio will be premiered with the Ahn Trio at the Southern Theatre in Columbus.

Organization Name: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
Project Description: To support the commission and premiere of a concerto for chamber orchestra and string quartet by Lera Auerbach with related outreach activities. The premiere will feature the Borromeo String Quartet with the orchestra.

Organization Name: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
Project Description: To support a commission of a new double concerto by composer Gabriela Lena Frank for piano, violoncello, and chamber orchestra. Guest artists David Finckel and Wu Han will join the orchestra, under the direction of Music Director Timothy Russell, to premiere the work at the Southern Theatre in Columbus.

Organization Name: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
Project Description: To support the commission and world premiere of a new work by composer Michael Daugherty. The ProMusica Chamber Orchestra, under the direction of music director Timothy Russell, will premiere the work as part of its 25th-anniversary celebration at the Southern Theatre in Columbus.

Organization Name: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
Project Description: To support a commission and premiere of a new work by composer Peter Schickele. The ProMusica Chamber Orchestra will premiere the work, a clarinet concerto, at the Southern Theatre in Columbus, OH.

Organization Name: ProMusica Chamber Orchestra of Columbus, Inc.
Project Description: To support a commission of a new work by composer Oliver Lake. The World Saxophone Quartet and the ProMusica Chamber Orchestra will premiere the work in November 2001 at the Southern Theatre in Columbus, OH.

Category: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
Project Description: Purpose: To support sensory-friendly rehearsal performances for adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Additional Project Description: The shows will be full performance-quality dress rehearsals that are more sensory-friendly than the nightly shows. ShadoArt Productions will work with partners Goodwill Columbus, Franklin County Board of Developmental Disabilities, ARC Industries, and Best Buddies to reach individuals enrolled in programs for individuals with disabilities. Visitors will have the opportunity to attend rehearsals in a way that accommodates their needs and allows them to be part of the theater-going community. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will primarily benefit individuals with disabilities in Columbus, Ohio. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries engage with the arts.

Discipline / Field: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act
Project Description: To support personnel costs in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Category: Challenge America: Arts Engagement in American Communities
Project Description: To support sensory-friendly matinee performances for adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. The shows will be open to the public, but are specifically designed to meet the needs of adults with disabilities. Visitors will have the opportunity to attend performances in a way that accommodates their needs and allows them to be part of theater-going community. The shows will include musicals, sketch-comedy, and rock-and-roll performances.

To support the creation and production of "Circle of Blood," a new multimedia theatrical work by Shadowbox Live. Created in collaboration with David Mack, author and illustrator of the "Kabuki" graphic novels, the production will combine kabuki makeup and masks, live action fight choreography, and original rock music to tell the story of a futuristic Japanese government operative known as Kabuki. The production will incorporate illustrations and images from the novels as scenic elements for the performance.

To support the creation of a modern production of "Tenshu Monogatari" by Shadowbox Live. The traditional Japanese Kabuki folktale will employ an original rock music score and incorporate highly physical, stylized movement with fight choreography, magic, and giant puppets. The production will be a collaboration with artist Hiromi Sakamoto and will feature modern Kabuki makeup styles designed by David Mack, author and illustrator of the "Kabuki" series of graphic novels. The project will provide a cross-cultural, multisensory experience for audiences, and will feature talkbacks with collaborators at several performances.

To support a summer writing camp for children in grades two through eight and writing workshops for older children and adults. Participants can focus on one topic or genre over a six-week period, or take different workshops each week on such issues as character development and writing for television.

To support a summer writing camp for children in grades two through eight and writing workshops for older children and adults. Past winners of the Thurber Prize for American Humor include Ian Frazier, Christopher Buckley, David Sedaris, and Jon Stewart.

To support performances of "Pierce to the Soul," produced by Contemporary American Theater Company and "Nobody's Perfect," produced by the kennedy Center Theater for Young Audiences. Pre- and post-performance discussions will be offered after each presentation.
To support a tour of "Go Dog. Go" by the Phoenix Theatre for Children. During the performance, actors will engage the student audience by teaching basic sign language that relates to the narrative.
To support activities that contribute to your creative development and artistic growth and may include writing, research, and travel.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: Purpose: To support the development and presentation of new work, with associated public programming. Additional Project Description: The Wex will commission and/or present projects by a diverse range of artists exploring climate change, environmental fragility, and planetary health. Media artist Hope Ginsburg will create Meditation Ocean, a video installation at the Wex highlighting the connections among art, marine life, and mindfulness. A.K. Burns' piece What is perverse is water will include a video installation and sculptural components focusing on water and economic, racial, and gender inequities. Theater group Ontroerend Goed will present their piece Are we not drawn onward to new erA, which explores the prospect of environmental apocalypse. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the participating artists and audiences in the Columbus, Ohio, area. Intended Outcome: Beneficiaries access arts activities and programming.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: Purpose: To support the development and presentation of new work, with associated public programming. Additional Project Description: Colombian-born, New York City-based interdisciplinary artist Carlos Motta will explore legacies of colonialism on BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color) and LGBTQIA+ populations. Indigenous performance collective New Red Order will research Ohio's Indigenous history and weave it into an ongoing project and feature film, Never Settle. Dominican-American multidisciplinary artist Joiri Minaya will explore Caribbean identity and histories of imperialism that exist in today's tourist industry. Additionally, the artists will participate in engagement activities including public workshops and discussions. Activities will take place either in person or online. Intended Beneficiaries: The project will benefit the participating artists and audiences in the Columbus area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: Purpose: To support artist residencies and production facilities at the Wexner Center's Film/Video Studio program. Additional Project Description: Local and visiting media artists will receive access to studio facilities and equipment, technical support, mentorship, and opportunities for public exhibition. Intended Beneficiaries: The program will serve participating artists, as well as general audiences in the greater Columbus, Ohio area. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation's cultural infrastructure.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Category: American Rescue Plan (ARP) Grants to Organizations
Project Description: Purpose: To support personnel and marketing expenses in response to and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Additional Project Description: The support will help the organization maintain operations during recovery from the devastating economic and health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Intended Beneficiaries: This assistance will benefit the organization’s constituency, such as arts workers, artists, and audiences. Intended Outcome: Artistic activities and traditions are supported to strengthen the nation’s cultural infrastructure.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the development and presentation of new work. Artists in disciplines including dance and multidisciplinary performance will create and present performances. Additionally, artists may participate in engagement activities including workshops and discussions. Activities will take place either in person or online.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support artist residencies and production facilities for the Wexner Center’s Film/Video Studio program. Resident filmmakers and artists, both emerging and established, will receive support through access to production facilities, technical support, mentorship, curatorial consultation, and public presentations of their work while developing new projects.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support series of multidisciplinary events. The programming, focused on jazz and experimental African-American music, will be designed in collaboration with jazz composer and drummer Mark Lomax, and will include a performance by his ensemble with a local choir. This curated series will include the premiere of the multimedia music and video work Let the Rhythm Hit 'Em, by DJ Krate Digga, as well as chamber concert showcasing African-American composers with cellist Timothy Holley.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support artist residencies, facilities access, and development of a web portal for the Film/Video Studio program. Resident filmmakers will receive support through access to production facilities, technical equipment, and curatorial consultation while developing new projects. Filmmakers such as Bill Morrison and artists designated by Barbara Hammer also will participate in year-long residencies to create new works, and will present their projects in master classes for area students, public screenings, and artist discussions. In addition, the Wexner Center will develop an online platform that provides public access to more than 400 works of art created through the Film/Video Studio program.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support an exhibition of visual art by jazz pianist and composer Jason Moran and related activities. An exhibition of Moran's visual work, including installations and charcoal drawings, will be mounted at the Wexner. Related engagement activities will include in-gallery jazz concerts, lectures, and discussions.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support artist residencies and facilities access for the Film/Video Studio program. Filmmakers will receive support through access to production facilities, technical equipment, and curatorial consultation while developing new projects. Artists Penny Lane, Jennifer Reeder, and Kevin Jerome Everson will participate in year-long residencies to create new works with a focus on Ohio, and will present their projects in master classes for area students, public screenings, and filmmaker discussions.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support a series of residencies and commissions. Choreographer Bebe Miller will participate in a creative residency to develop new work. Additionally, the Wexner will present a multimedia collaboration between the Kronos Quartet and filmmaker Sam Green, as well as present British theater company Improbable. Artists also will participate in engagement activities including student discussions, master classes, and post-show question-and-answer sessions.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support a series of residencies and commissions. Choreographer Faye Driscoll, visual artist Sarah Oppenheimer, and Ohio-based musician/composer Brian Harnetty will each participate in residencies to develop and premiere new works at the Wexner Center. In addition to residency activities, the artists will participate in lectures, discussions, and master classes. Online resources and social media will enhance the public outreach with the artists and their work.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support an artist residency, year-round film screenings, and other related activities. During the project period, artist-in-residence Kevin Everson will create new works and visiting filmmakers will present their films. Works range from experimental multi-channel installations to documentary and narrative films.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support an artist residency and presenting program. Artists include choreographer/dancer Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui(Belgium) and filmmaker Liza Johnson (United States), as well as composer and vocal artist Samita Sinha (United States) in collaboration with video artist/sculptor Dani Leventhal (United States). In addition to residency activities, the artists will participate in discussions, master classes, staged readings, and film screenings.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support multidisciplinary creative residencies, commissions, and presentations. The Wexner Center will host SITI Company in collaboration with visual artist Ann Hamilton for the creation of an interdisciplinary performance installation work. As part of the Via Brasil initiative, the center will present extended residencies with visual artist Jonathas de Andrade and a Brazilian video artist.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support Creative Residencies and Commissioning projects. Artists will participate in residency activities, including the creative development of new works, and related engagement activities.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support an artist residency and presenting program. Artists will receive technical and professional services that will enable them to create, complete, and present works in the performing and visual arts.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support an artist residency program at the Wexner Center for the Arts. Artists will receive technical and professional services that will enable them to create, complete, and present works in the performing and media arts.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support an artist residency program. Artists will receive technical and professional services that will enable them to create, complete, and present works in the performing and media arts.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support a series of performances and installations by American dancer/choreographer William Forsythe (1949-). Recognized not only in the field of dance, but also in visual arts and design, Forsythe's gallery-based performances and installation works Everywhere and Nowhere at the Same Time, City of Abstracts, White Bouncy Castle, Antipodes, and Solo will be presented by Wexner.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support creative residencies and presentations of visual, performing, and media art works.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support creative residencies and presentations of visual, performing, and media art works. The program will provide technical and professional support for the creation, completion, and presentation of works in the visual, performing, and media arts.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support creative residencies and presentations of visual, performing, and media art works. The project is part of an ongoing artist residency program that provides technical and professional support for the creation, completion, and presentation of new work.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support creative residencies and presentation of visual, performing, and media art works. The project is part of an ongoing artists' residency program that provides technical and professional support for the creation, completion, and/or presentation of new work.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the commissioning of visual, performing, and media art works. The project is part of Wexner Center for the Arts' ongoing artists' residency program that provides financial, technical, and professional support for the creation, completion, and/or presentation of new work.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the commissioning of visual, performing, and media art works. The project is a part of the Wexner Center for the Arts' ongoing artists residency program that provides financial, technical, and professional support for the creation, completion, and/or presentation of art.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Category: Challenge America Positive Alternatives for Youth
Project Description: To support a partnership project of artist-led activities that provides positive alternatives for youth. The partnership with Department of Art, Advanced Computing Center for the Arts and Design, and Chadwick Aboretum at Ohio State University, and the Davis Performing Arts Center and Center of Science and Industry will conduct summer multidisciplinary arts workshops for children and youth at the Wexner Center.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the commissioning of visual, performing, and media art works. This project is a part of the Wexner Center for the Arts' ongoing artists residency program that provides financial, technical, and professional support for the creation, completion, and/or presentation of art.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the artists residency program for the creation, completion, and the presentation of visual, performing, and media art works. This project is part of the Wexner Center for the Arts' ongoing artists' residency program that provides financial, technical, and professional support for the creation, completion, and/or the presentation of the art.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the artist residency and commission program of financial, technical, and professional support for up to 28 artists to create, complete, and present new works. All of the artists in residence will participate in community workshops, free concerts for elementary and middle school students, master classes, open rehearsals, symposia, and roundtable discussions.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support the Wexner Center for the Arts artists' residency program which provides financial, technical and professional support for the creation, completion or presentation of works. The 1999-2000 residencies will be complemented by presentations of leading artists to commemorate the Center's tenth anniversary and the Millennium.

Popular Name: aka Wexner Center for the Arts
Project Description: To support a residency program in which up to 10 artists will be provided with financial, technical, and professional assistance to create, complete, or present works in the performing, visual, or media arts to benefit the artists, Ohio University students and faculty, the greater community, and the various arts fields. This project provides artists with the opportunity to develop ideas, while at the same time fostering interaction between artists and the larger community through open rehearsals, symposia, and workshops. As part of a university, the Wexner Center is in a unique position to build upon creative residencies through direct links with the campus. Additionally, this institution is the primary resource through which the local public can experience and better understand the arts of our time. Residencies are proposed by the curatorial staff using certain criteria: artists who are at a moment in their career when they need the space and time to take their work in a new direction; artists who need funds, physical resources, and technical support to complete a work-in-progress; and artists whose work might go unrealized if not for the facilities and support available. Artists under consideration are, in the visual arts, Dan Graham and Illya Kabakov; in media arts, Tacita Dean and Phillip Johnston, a composer and performer who has become an innovative film soundtrack artist. In addition, an artist will be invited to work in the
